abstract.p: Valentine Wilber letter on April 8 Why We Travel item about Human Rights Watch intern's train trip through West Africa

block.p: To the Editor: In the years since I was a Peace Corps volunteer in Senegal, more prestigious positions have opened up, as the ''Why We Travel: West Africa'' (April 8) segment amply demonstrates. To the Editor: In the years since I was a Peace Corps volunteer in Senegal, more prestigious positions have opened up, as the ''Why We Travel: West Africa'' (April 8) segment amply demonstrates. Yet the young interviewee's seven-month internship with Human Rights Watch in Dakar, Senegal, seems to have taught her little if anything.

She refers to a trip she took as ''this crazy loop through West Africa,'' commencing with something she terms a ''ghost train.'' I have taken this same trip, and yes, it is a very tough one, but I do not recall it proceeding at ''about five kilometers an hour.''

So many people in this young woman's position seem to regard the travel period after their brief -- and apparently meaningless -- internships as a tour through their private preserve during which they can degrade whomever they please.

And then there is the interviewee's seatmate, whom she flippantly names Madame Crazy. Yes, I have seen aberrant and at times bizarre behavior in Senegal, a land with very little help for mental health problems, and yet it is the home of many proud and generous people.

Perhaps the possibility that Mme. Crazy might just have had a skin condition, not uncommon in such an arid land, was overlooked. I suffered the same while in the Peace Corps, and would not give my experience there for all the Human Rights internships in the world.
